title: High rollers: Inside CeramicSpeed’s HQ

High rollers: Inside CeramicSpeed’s HQ

The flight from London to Billund in the west of Denmark is a short one, the kind where it feels like no sooner have you gone up than you’re on your way back down. Such a quick transfer makes the contrast between the grubby bustle of our capital and the serene cleanliness of Denmark’s rural west especially stark.

A sense of calm percolates through the place. Everything from car journeys to restaurant menus is well ordered and precise. It isn’t hard to see why the area gave rise to the creation of Lego, which originated in Billund in 1932. Or CeramicSpeed, a bearing and components company that has developed a reputation for quality and performance in the cycling world and beyond.

Considering it now distributes in more than 50 countries and supplies the military and aerospace as well as cycling, it’s hard to believe CeramicSpeed started in the living room of founder Jacob Csizmadia as recently as the late 1990s. Today the brand’s modern, monolithic headquarters take up a fair chunk of an industrial park just outside the town of Holstebro, though it hasn’t moved far from its birthplace.

‘Jacob lives next door,’ says Martin Banke, CeramicSpeed’s managing director. ‘When the company began to expand, Jacob was adamant that it needed to stay in the area. He wanted to support Holstebro’s local community with job opportunities, and he knew the community was the secret to our success. As you’ve seen, a strong work ethic that values precision and repeatability is in the culture around here.’

One technician can assemble 50 common bearings in an hour, and quality control is done by man as much as machine.

‘These guys are so attuned they can tell if a bearing has been incorrectly assembled by feel, even by how it sounds,’ says Banke. ‘Bearings should have 50 to 60 microns of play in them so they’re correctly preloaded once installed.’

Such commitment from its employees is rewarded with, or perhaps inspired by, an airy and bright working environment. Huge windows let in piercingly bright Scandinavian sunlight as well as forming large parts of the walls separating one room from another.

‘We wanted our departments to feel connected because no matter whether our staff are in assembly or accounts they’re equally integral to the company,’ says Banke.

The premises are laid out in order of production. Balls and races start at one end of the building and the packaged product leaves at the other. No matter where you are in the building, however, it’s immaculate. The bearing assembly areas have the air of an operating theatre. While CeramicSpeed’s surgeons go about their tasks in a more relaxed manner, their job has to be no less exact: CeramicSpeed’s ball bearings are sized in increments of 2.5 microns (the diameter of a human hair is around 70 microns) and every bearing is made to order.

Those orders come from several industries. CeramicSpeed makes anything from tiny pulley wheel bearings to huge ones, 30cm or more across, that are fitted into things like tank turrets. Other, super-light ones go into satellites. The largest ‘bearing’ the company has ever made, though, is kept in house. It’s a light fitting that occupies a huge central column in the middle of the building, made to a 1:150 scale of the first bearing size Czismadia ever made: the 608.

The company founder just so happens to be making coffee nearby when we reach the fixture.

‘Man, it looks cool but that thing was a nightmare,’ Czismadia says. ‘It’s made from wood and just veneered in aluminum. As a true scale model, using the same materials as the bearing it’s based on, it would weigh 12 tonnes. The carpenters that made it hated me. To this day it’s the hardest product we’ve ever made.’

Get your skates on

That’s quite the statement given the scale of the company today, but CeramicSpeed’s forest grew from a single seed, says Banke: ‘In the 1990s Jacob was a serious inline speed skater. That’s where his interest in bearings came from. He got in touch with SKF, which is essentially the Shimano of the bearing world, about sponsorship, and they supplied him with some of the first hybrid ceramics outside of aerospace.

Hybrid ceramic means the balls are ceramic and the races are steel, which is the composition of our bearings today. He quickly learned what worked and what didn’t, made some tweaks, then shattered the skating world record, covering 505km in 24 hours – around a supermarket, believe it or not. After that, SKF employed him as an external consultant so they could develop hybrid ceramic bearings for sport applications.’

Initially Csizmadia thought roller skates would be the focus, but it was clear pretty quickly that cycling showed greater potential.

‘Jacob travelled with Team CSC to the 2000 Tour de France and upgraded their products,’ says Banke. ‘He arrived with high hopes of making a splash, as he and SKF had done their testing and demonstrated an appreciable reduction in friction. He quicky learned there were other “upgrades” in play at the time where you could gain much more without messing around with your equipment. CSC were very happy, however, and team manager Bjarne Riis endorsed us from the beginning.’

Csizmadia experienced more headwinds at the OEM level trying to get SKF’s bearings into wheel manufacturers.

‘SKF is enormous. They make as many bearings in a day as we do in a year,’ says Banke. ‘And wheel brands back then were tentatively looking at this new technology, asking for ten custom bearings for one test, then 100 for the next step. Then when it was accepted, the order was comparatively small, for SKF anyway, so it just wasn’t viable for a company of their size.’

Csizmadia recognised that scale was the issue, so he left SKF to start CeramicSpeed in 2004, working out of his apartment in Holstebro.

‘Maxing out a credit card, he bought the highest-quality ceramic balls he could afford and started assembling custom bearings, selling into bike shops and clubs. With the profit he bought more. Before long he got in with FSA, which was the first brand to launch a proper range of products with ceramic bearings in the mid-2000s – bottom brackets and hubs. Jacob supplied FSA with the bearings. It helped him hugely as that gave him proper volume and he could expand.

‘When I came on board in 2010 he had distributors around the world, but it was essentially just people who had asked to sell in their territory. I came with a pretty big global contact network, so we started to build a more coherent and specific distribution model.’

Stepping out of the shadows

This set the foundation for CeramicSpeed to become the company it is today, but Banke says it wouldn’t have got to where it is without a couple of flashpoints.

‘The first was our OSPW [oversized pulley wheel system] in 2015,’ he says. ‘We went from being invisible on a bike to being a focal point. That dovetailed with the rise of social media, so our brand awareness just exploded.’

The stimulus for the product was a report from Friction Facts, an efficiency test facility in Boulder, Colorado, that CeramicSpeed later acquired, which showed how spring tension and pulley wheel size affect drivetrain friction.

Reducing spring tension (how forcefully the derailleur spring tensions the chain) and upper pulley size makes a drivetrain more efficient. Banke and Csizmadia thought they could add an extra layer by incorporating ceramic bearings.

‘The original OSPW was made by Wolfgang Berner and used by Fabian Cancellara in 2010. We give all the credit in the world to Berner for his ingenuity, but thought we could make his design even better,’ says Banke.

It was the OSPW that put CeramicSpeed on the map in the cycling, but the brand’s second watershed moment transcended the sport. Driven was a drivetrain concept that eschewed the chain and derailleurs, using instead a driveshaft to connect the sprockets and chainring.

‘It stemmed from the same place as all our products – to make a bike more efficient – but was approached without any preconceived notions about what the drivetrain should look like,’ says Banke. ‘We took it to Eurobike in 2018 and the world went crazy for it. Mainstream media ran stories on it; parents at my children’s kindergarten with no interest in cycling would approach me and ask about it. A while after, we had an agency assess the impact it made. They reckon it got 1.2 billion digital impressions.’

In its original guise the Driven project has since been paused but Banke says the impact on CeramicSpeed has been undeniable. The brand is now considered a market leader and continues to innovate.

Most recently it has been leading the way in maintenance-free bearings: its SLT range (Solid Lubricant Technology) self-lubricates using an oil-infused polymer, a big advantage for bikes where cables are routed through bearings and servicing is time-consuming and costly.

‘Product sustainability is a big focus for us,’ says Banke. ‘I think the high-performance aspect of our products is well appreciated, but we want to communicate that they are also tough enough to last until you don’t ride that bike anymore.’

As a result, CeramicSpeed is now often approached by bike and wheel makers that want to base designs around the brand’s products.

‘That’s where I see one of our opportunities in future, collaborating with partners,’ says Banke.

That’s enough of an open-ended statement to let the imagination run wild. Maybe bike and wheel brands today, but groupset integration tomorrow – Dura-Ace Di2 with a built-in OSPW and CeramicSpeed bottom bracket? It’s a long shot but, given CeramicSpeed’s track record, you wouldn’t bet against it.

Driving forward

A radical reimagining of how the bicycle is driven

‘We were inspired by the Nike Breaking2 project, which used runner Eliud Kipchoge in an attempt to break the marathon two-hour barrier,’ says Martin Banke, CeramicSpeed’s managing director.

‘We liked how they combined the storytelling and ambition with the development of a new product. A worthy, exciting cause doubling up as marketing platform to launch something is an excellent strategy, so we set up our own – the pursuit of the 1% drivetrain.

‘We aimed to make a drivetrain that would only consume 1% of the energy put into it by the rider. Even with our upgrades, a conventional drivetrain is only around 96% efficient. The Driven driveshaft concept came out of that in 2018.

‘We took it to Eurobike and it stole the show – there was just a crazy amount of attention around it. People quickly pointed out the challenges of changing gear, etc, but we were convinced we could make it more than a concept.

‘Ultimately the challenges to turn it into a commercial project were insurmountable. Today the team behind Driven has developed an e-bike drive system from it.’

Spheres of influence

How CeramicSpeed’s balls are made

While CeramicSpeed can legitimately call its bearings its own, some of the subcomponents for a lot of its sizes are outsourced. Swedish bearings company SKF often supplies the races and cages, for example, and sometimes even full bearings that CeramicSpeed then takes apart, customises with its own balls, then reassembles.

‘The balls are what make our bearings special,’ says CeramicSpeed managing director Martin Banke. ‘No one else in the industry uses such high-quality ingredients or takes as long to have them made. Our balls are made from silicon nitride powder, which is pressed at 1,600 bar and 1,800°C. They come out of the moulds “rough” so are then mixed with diamond powder and churned for 50 to 70 days to gently abrade them into perfect spheres.’

Hybrid ceramic bearings were first developed for high-speed use, such as in jet engines, which has caused doubt over their efficacy in a bicycle application.

‘You still get the benefits of low friction and longevity on a bike,’ says Banke. ‘There is the potential for the opposite to be true – as the balls are harder than the races, they could cut into them and wear them out. This is where we stand apart.

‘Because our balls are perfectly round, they polish the races rather than abrade them. Then versus steel balls when the bearing gets contaminated with debris, our balls crush it outright. In comparison, steel balls, being softer, push debris into the race where it lodges and accelerates wear.’
